title: Eliseo Valdez Sr.
body:
Eliseo Valdez Sr., a World War II veteran who so proudly served his country in the United States Navy, was called by the Lord on Monday, Dec. 16, 2013.
 After serving his country and marrying the love of his life, Lucinda Valdez, he took great pride in working tirelessly all his life as a strong labor leader with the AFL-CIO.
 As a labor leader in our community, he organized two of the biggest strikes in Laredo for fair wages, better working conditions and better benefits.
 His legacy as a strong labor leader will long be remembered by all the lives he helped make better.
 To his children and grandchildren, he was bigger than life and totally fearless.
 Although far from perfect, in our own minds and hearts he has always been our hero.
 He leaves a big void in our hearts, but the comfort we have is that we know he accepted the Lord Jesus Christ as his Lord and Savior, and because of that, we will meet and rejoice with him in Heaven someday.
 Mr. Eliseo Valdez Sr. is preceded in death by his parents, Enrique and Angelina Valdez Sr.; and his brothers: Enrique Jr., Jose Alberto and Jose H. Valdez.
 He is survived by his loving wife, Lucinda Valdez; loving grandson, Servando (Rommie) Iruegas; brother, Valentin Valdez; sisters, Octavia Martinez and Olivia (Enrique) Villanueva; children: former City Councilman Eliseo (Rosario) Valdez Jr., Judge Danny (Mary) Valdez, Geraldine (former City Councilman Alfredo) Agredano and Rudy (Leticia) Valdez;
loving grandchildren: Gabriel (Julie) Valdez and Joseph Valdez, Maribel Valdez and Danny Valdez Jr., Lorena (Marco Antonio) Tijerina, and Lucy, Alfredo Jr., Frances, Marco Antonio, Selina and Ysenia Agredano, and Christopher Valdez;
great-grandchildren: Zoe and Gavin Valdez, Jillian L. Iruegas, Mia and Rene Rodriguez, Marco Antonio, Gladys and Miguel Angel Tijerina, and Ashton Agredano.  He is also survived by numerous cousins, nieces, nephews and friends.
 Special thanks go to Regent Care Center -- especially the staff of the Blanco Wing -- for the exceptional care provided to Mr. Valdez.
 Visitation will be held Thursday, Dec. 19, 2013, at Joe Jackson North Funeral Chapels, 1410 Jacaman Road, from 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. A chapel service will be held at 7 p.m. Interment will be held at a later date.
 You may extend your condolences to the family online at www.joejacksonfuneralchapels.com.
 Arrangements are under the direction of the funeral service professionals at Joe Jackson North Funeral Chapels, 1410 Jacaman Road, Laredo, TX 78041, 956-722-8850.

title: Certificada la prohibición de las bolas de goma a partir de mayo
body:
Jaume Bosch, de ICV, estudia un gráfico de EL PERIÓDICO con los dos tipos de fusiles antidisturbios, ayer.
 El próximo 1 de mayo, Catalunya será territorio libre de pelotas de goma.  El Parlament, en una histórica votación realizada ayer, acordó vetar esta polémica munición, que en los últimos cinco años ha causado mutilaciones oculares a siete personas y ha herido de gravedad a otras cuatro.  El pleno de la Cámara catalana aprobó con 76 votos a favor, 30 en contra y 22 abstenciones el punto 24 de las conclusiones de la Comisión de Estudio de los Modelos de Seguridad y Orden Público y del Uso de Material Antidisturbios en los Acontecimientos de Masas, en que se insta a Interior a "iniciar inmediatamente la retirada de las pelotas de goma, que se han de sustituir gradualmente, de manera que en fecha del 30 de abril del 2014 sea efectiva la prohibición total".  Hasta entonces, las pelotas de goma quedan relegadas a instrumento "de último recurso".
 A favor votaron CiU, ERC y Ciutadans.  El PSC se abstuvo e ICV-EUiA y la CUP votaron en contra pues querían también la prohibición de los proyectiles viscoelásticos con que se van a reeemplazar.  Por su parte, el PP votó en contra pues, en palabras del diputado Pere Calbó, esta prohibición "es una irresponsabilidad que lamina la seguridad en Catalu-nya y que demuestra que el Govern carece de un modelo de seguridad".
 El documento señala que se "ha de garantizar en cualquier caso la disponibilidad de herramientas robustas" que reemplacen a las pelotas de goma.  Por el momento, la conselleria, que sigue apostando por un modelo de antidisturbios basado en que los agentes mantengan la distancia con los manifestantes, ha ordenado la compra de casi medio centenar de fusiles lanzadores de proyectiles viscoelásticos, que en teoría son menos lesivos que las pelotas de goma.  De hecho, las conclusiones avalan el uso por parte de Interior del cañón de agua, aunque recomiendan que se conciba como "herramienta de último recurso".
 En cualquier caso, el informe del Parlament ordena que, tanto con las bolas de goma (mientras duren) como con los viscoelásticos, los Mossos realicen "una informatización del inventario" para poder determinar con exactitud cuántos proyectiles se disparan y quién los dispara.
 El diputado de ICV-EUiA Jaume Bosch se felicitó por el fin de las pelotas pero lamentó "que sigan otros proyectiles".  "Reemplazamos un tipo de fusil por otro tipo de fusil y un tipo de proyectil por otro tipo de proyectil", comentó, y reprochó a CiU y ERC el haber vetado una resolución por la cual el Parlament pedía disculpas a las víctimas.  Para David Fernàndez, de la CUP, "esta votación es una victoria de las víctimas" y permite eliminar un artefacto que causa "lesiones de guerra".
 ATENCIÓN A LAS VÍCTIMAS / El informe establece por primera vez una pauta de conducta hacia las víctimas de las actuaciones policiales, que hasta ahora eran dejadas en el más absoluto desamparo.  Así, Interior debe elaborar "un protocolo de reparación del daño para la indemnización" de las víctimas, que ha de ser retroactivo.  Además, se debe establecer un "sistema de atención de las víctimas causadas por disturbios, que permita ofrecer servicios de asistencia y acompañamiento psicológico, sanitario y social".

title: Apple requiring app submissions to be optimized for iOS 7 by Feb. 1
body:
All developers will be required to submit apps that are compatible with iOS 7 and built with Xcode 5 as of February 1, 2014
According to a post on Apple's developer website, all developers will be required to submit apps that are compatible with iOS 7 and built with Xcode 5 as of February 1, 2014.
 Until now, the App Store has been accepting the submission of both apps that were built from the ground up for iOS 7 as well as those that were built for iOS 6 using older versions of the company's developer toolset.  This was done primarily as a temporary measure, so that companies with existing apps wouldn't have to choose between abandoning their users who chose not to upgrade to the latest version of Apple's operating system or supporting both iOS 6 and 7 in a single executable--which, given the user interface differences between the two versions of iOS, would be a pretty significant challenge.
 Instead, Apple built much of the "old" iOS 6 UI into iOS 7, allowing developers to take advantage of it if they so chose.  As developer liaison David Duncan explained earlier this month on one of the company's mailing lists, this means that apps built against the older operating system "get a compatible styling (it[']s not exactly iOS 6, and it[']s certainly not iOS 7, but it[']s somewhere in between while still looking like an iOS 6 app)." "
As adoption of iOS 7 continues to grow at a rapid pace, the need for iOS 6 compatibility is waning, and it's likely that Apple has simply chosen to forego support for apps built against the older interface for a couple reasons.  First, keeping programmers on a particular set of tools means having to support fewer different technologies--on a large scale, this means that Apple's engineers will need to keep track fewer pieces of software and be able to focus their developer assistance efforts on a smaller range of possible issues.
 In the longer run, getting rid of iOS 6 support will also make iOS 7 (and its successors) easier to maintain and smaller--a definite plus as the operating system continues to grow in complexity and the company's ecosystem plays host to an increasing number of devices.
 Note, however, that this doesn't mean that Apple is preventing developers from submitting versions of their apps that will work on older versions of iOS--as long as they fully support iOS 7's native interface paradigms as well.  Likewise, existing apps are grandfathered in as long they aren't updated, but any subsequent updates will have to adhere to the rule.
 In practice, however, given how different iOS 7's UI is, it's likely that many developers will themselves forego support for previous iOS versions, resulting in fewer choices for owners of devices that, like the first-generation iPad and iPhone 3GS, cannot be updated to the most recent releases of Apple's mobile software.

title: FIA wraps year with must-see exhibits
body:
FLINT -- Only two weeks remain before Toulouse-Lautrec & His World leaves the FIA and this continent, so Michiganians should not miss this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to see 150 works on paper by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, rarely seen outside of Europe.
 Running through Dec. 30, the exhibition features many one-of-akind drawings and posters capturing the essence of the Parisian social scene, dance halls, brothels, theatres and the famous Moulin Rouge Lautrec was immersed in.
 "This remarkable collection of Lautrec's art on loan from the Heraklaidon Museum in Athens, Greece, has been drawing visitors to the Flint Institute of Arts from throughout the Midwest," said John Henry, Director.  "Toulouse-Lautrec has been described as the Andy Warhol of 19th century Paris -- taking commercial imagery and elevating it to fine art, consequently becoming much of a celebrity, in his own right, as the performers he immortalized." "
Also on view through the holidays are the exhibitions Beatrice Wood: Mama of Dada and Walk on the Wild Side: Animals and Other Creatures in Art.  The FIA is open Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday from 12-5 p.m., Thursday 12-9 p.m., Saturday 10 a.m.-5 p.m. and Sunday 1-5 p.m.
Holiday hours are as follows: Dec. 24, 25, closed; Dec. 26, 12-5 p.m. with no Happy Hour; Dec. 31 and Jan. 1, closed.
 The Flint Institute of Arts is located just two blocks off I-475 in the Flint Cultural Center between the University of Michigan-Flint and Mott Community College.  Admission to the FIA permanent collection is free; admission to the Toulouse-Lautrec exhibition is $7 for Adults, $5 for Senior Citizens and Students and FREE to FIA members and children under 12.  -- G.G.

title: 'The Voice' champ quips about Jamaica's bad roads
body:
Jamaican singer Tessanne Chin just might motivate the government of her Caribbean homeland to fix the country's chronically rutted roads.
 Chin became the season five champ of "The Voice" TV show Tuesday, eliciting jubilation in Jamaica.  Her performances on the NBC singing competition were a big topic on the island for weeks and politicians lost no time in congratulating her.
 When Chin won a car with the other show finalists, she quipped to host Carson Daly that "we have the worst roads" in Jamaica.
 National Works Agency Deputy CEO Earl Patterson said Wednesday that he got the message, telling reporters: "Certainly the point that Tessanne made that the roads could do with more investment, that point is noted." "
However, he quickly added that the island's fiscal constraints must be considered.

title: Ricardo Rendón, de Abracadabra: "Historias divertidas pero que dejen poso"
body:
¡NO!
 Marta Altès
Thule.  12,95 €
Un libro muy, muy divertido de la joven ilustradora catalana Marta Altès, que ha empezado a ser publicada en Londres, donde se ha ido a vivir.  Un perro cree que su nombre es ¡No! porque cada vez que hace algo bien (probar la comida de sus amos antes que ellos para asegurarse de que esté buena, tirar de la correa para que así puedan correr más rápido por el parque) gritan su nombre a pleno pulmón.  Pronto la traducción al catalán.
 SOY PEQUEÑITO
Juanjo Arjona y Emilio Urbenaga
A Buen Paso.  16 €
Para el protagonista, el parque es una selva, una escalera, una montaña, un perro suelto es un lobo salvaje y un charco, un río que hay que vadear con esfuerzo.  "Es una historia muy bonita: lo que significa ser pequeño y tener valentía y arrojo para salir y conocer el mundo, y la maravilla de hacerlo sin estar solo, con alguien que te da la mano".
 LA ZANAHORIA GIGANTE
Satoe Tone
Ediciones La Fragatina.  14,50 €
Ricardo Rendón, responsable de la multilingüe librería infantil Abracadabra (Álvarez de Castro, 5, Barcelona), centró su selección en libros para menores de 8 años.  Empieza con este libro en el que seis conejos, hermanos, le buscan utilidades a una zanahoria gigante (acaban, claro, comiéndosela, que por algo son roedores).  "Le dan vueltas a un objeto y empiezan a imaginarse cosas sobre él.  El texto hace dar vueltas a la imaginación", destaca.  Y la ilustración, de primera.
 GATO ROJO.  GATO AZUL / EL GAT VERMELL.  EL GAT BLAU
Jenni Desmond
Lata de Sal.  15,95 €
Un gato rojo que envidia la inteligencia de un gato azul.  Un gato azul que envidia la agilidad del gato rojo.  Hacen mil y una trastadas para cambiar de color (pero esa no es la cuestión).  "Una historia simpática y una ilustración muy compleja con apariencia simple.  Esta bien ir formando el sentido estético a los niños".

label.eng: Odón de Buen y del Cos

title: Scots foreign aid jobs face threat from independence vote
body:
A report from the International Development Committee also cast doubt over a separate Scotland's ability to provide significant help to developing countries as it would be a "much smaller player".
 The Scottish HQ of the Department for International Development (DFID) in East Kilbride employs 604 staff and contractors.  But the report warns that either the department would have to be grossly overstaffed in an independent Scotland, or the number of jobs would need to be cut to about 100.
 The committee chairman and Gordon Lib Dem MP Sir Malcolm Bruce warned: "The impact on jobs would be substantial." "
From 2013, the UK Government plans to spend 0.7 per cent of economic output on overseas aid.  Earlier this year Scottish International Development Minister Humza Yousaf pledged that an independent Scotland would enshrine the 0.7 per cent target in law.
 But Sir Malcolm said: "The DFID is a world leader in its field, and, as a big player on the world stage, the UK also wields considerable influence in multilateral organisations.
 "As part of the UK, Scotland makes a tremendous contribution.  Scots have served as development ministers in the UK Government, and three Scottish MPs, including myself, sit on the International Development Committee.  If Scotland were to become an independent country, its development agency would inevitably be a much smaller player." "
